reviewText:
Clumsy controls, unforgivable puzzles, old school knockback when struck, this is not what makes 2D exploration platformers good, it's what dates them when compaired to other more sucessful games in the genre.

I'll be fair and say that there is a lot of good going for La-Mulana, a nice 16-bit art style accompanied by some wonderful music really brings home the feeling of playing a classic SNES in your own home. On top of that, this is part of a genre I really love and don't see very many games of this type. The only recent one I can think of is Dust: An Elysian Tail. La-Mulana perfectly replicates the experience of exploring a treasure filled booby trapped temple. And there in lies the overall problem with the game.

First off, controls in this are very floaty at best, while movement and attacking is fine, if you jump you are committed to it up until a certain point in the air, which leads to some very tricky and downright frustrating moments of platforming. Adding to that, if you are hit by something and the area requires lots of jumping, you will be sent flying and can only recover movement upon landing on the ground ala: old school Castlevania. When a lot of exploration in this game relies upon pixel perfect platforming, getting hit not only hinders advancement, but also can be unavoidable at times. This can be especially bad when you are fighting big bosses that sometimes take up the entire screen and force you to move from platform to platform, or clumsily jump around in hopes of dodging that one fireball while at low health.

Puzzles in this game are what really drives in the decision to purchase this or not, as they can be downright unforgivable and just don't teach you how they effect the rest of the game. Two switches, one could be a trap that leaves you with the only choice to restart your game, one just activates another puzzle in a distant room, oh and if you don't get a certain item... you're ♥♥♥♥ed! Want to know what this item is? We ain't going to tell ya, you just have to solve more puzzles to find it... if you're lucky! If you're not lucky, the only choice you have is to use the RESET feature in the settings. You will use this often as the game just loves to trap you without any prior warning. And to top that all off, you had better save often because these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments will occur often, and sometimes at a time where hours of progress will be lost!

Teaching the player about the game over time is especially important to this genre, trial and error gameplay only serve to punish those who do not know better or are just starting out, and having a reset the game function is not the right way to fix such an inherently flawed puzzle system. Throughout all of the game I was lost, unable to solve the basic of puzzles, and would find myself trapped for making a beginner's mistake. The game barely teaches you it's basics unless you go out of your way to purchase necessary equipment that is needed to beat the game.

A good exploration game requires the tightest of controls, intelegent/clever puzzles, and the right conveyance to teach players as they play so that they can grow smarter and stronger. A bad one puts you into impossible situations where you cannot win and says Oh well
date: start over from the beginning and do it right this time!". I found this frustrating on my first 12 hours
recommended: I'm sure it would be better on a second playthrough
hoursPlayed: but I strongly believe first impressions are the most important thing when it comes to a game
voteText: and I cannot recommend this game as there are better alternatives out there.\n\nPlay Dust: An Elysian Tail
helpfulPercent: Castlevania: SotN
votesHelpful: and/or Super Metroid instead. Just pass on La-Mulana."

reviewText:
+Great metroidvania elements
+Huge explorable temple labyrinth with lots of secrets
+Weapons/upgrades/shops
+Bosses
+Puzzles

-Abnormal, counter-intuitive jump physics (simulating an old system doesn't excuse it for me)
-Lots of cheap joke" deaths (e.g.
date:
a switch that appears to open a door but is an instant death trap. HILARIOUS.)
-"Puzzles" can be a matter of accidentally stumbling onto some secret gimmick rather than figuring out a presented problem.
-Have I mentioned the positively awful jump physics?

There is a good game in here if you're a veteran of its particular flavor of old school jankiness and are fine with all of the modern gameplay lessons it proudly refuses to adhere to. Otherwise
recommended: you're going to have to tolerate a lot of petty annoyances for this one.\n\nThis game is soooo close to exactly what I want
hoursPlayed: but damn. Just misses the mark."

reviewText: I was torn between recommending this game or not, but the sheer amount of frustration at the end makes me say no.  On the plus side, the gameplay once you get used to it is fun, the boss battles are enjoyable challenges in a throw the controller throught the monitor sortof way, and some of the puzzles are clever.  That being said (and admittedly I probably am not the target audience for this game), the 'puzzles' at the end aren't so much difficult as being completely off in left field.  After the first half, I was pretty much playing via the walkthrough--which is unfortunate, because I know I could have figured some of the  things out on my own.  Since the unfair puzzles are so numerous, its simply discouraging to try your hand at any of them.  Travelling around in some fields becomes such a chore that it detracts from the entire experince (I'm looking at you chamber of birth).

reviewText: This game is fun as all hell for the first few hours, then it becomes so incredibly cryptic that you need a guide or youtube video to progress further into the game. My problem with this game isn't the controls, the difficult enemies or even the unfair traps; it's the fact that there's no direction whatsoever. You know how in Dark Souls you eventually start to hit all the walls you see looking for a hidden or how in the original DOOM games you go OOMPH against everything looking for some sort of easter egg? That's literally the gist of this game, hitting every wall and scanning everything just so you can progress a slight bit. The hints" that you get are vague at best and often times they aren't even near the puzzle
date: they're in another part of the ruins entirely.\n\nThere's a lot of comparisons to Dark Souls with this game
recommended: but I think it's more like Demon's Souls: an unrefined prelude to a great game. Similar to Demon's Souls

reviewText:
I am all for challenging games and figuring out puzzles but this game is beyond silly. You have to hit switches that magically do something in another room somewhere in the level (it could be in ANY room and you have to backtrack to 20+ rooms to find it). Sometimes you have to walk through an invisible wall, sometimes you have to set a rotating stone then figure out what it changed in who knows what room.

I am sure there are some people who will really like this style of game. To everyone who says this is like Demon/Dark Souls, you are completely wrong (It is more like The Battle of Olympus for NES). Just because if you die you start over from a save spot does not mean it is like those games. You can save anytime you want with this and you keep all your stuff. I wouldn't even call this game difficult because it is pretty easy jumping over traps and whipping bad guys. It just takes a ridiculous amount of time to figure out what everything does and for me, that is not fun.

The music is very good and I thought the controls were decent (using an xbox controller).

Overall though, this was a terrible gaming experience and as much as I hate leaving games unfinished, this just isn't worth the time. It is not fun for me to have to look at a guide to figure out what I am missing every 15 minutes. 5/10.

reviewText:
I like  metroidvania type games quite a bit so I picked this up. I really want to like this game but I cannot. The game contains elements that should have died back in the SNES era.
Enemies respawn once you leave a room.
Jump controls do not feel natural.
Walking off of a ledge locks you into a vertical fall, which is frustrating.

You will rarely feel like you are making actual progress because every other room will need an item from somewhere else or require you to solve a puzzle somewhere far away. There is never any clear or intuitive route for progression. Even with maps and walkthroughs open I have a great deal of difficulty figuring out where I am going or how to progress.

Hints are often useless because they will not be found with the puzzles they correspond to, or will be far too cryptic. There is no way to record hints either, so you will likely forget them long before they become relavent. Some puzzles are so unintuitive that they cannot be solved on your own, such as one puzzle where you must first collect an item from somewhere far away from the puzzle, bring it to the correct room, pause the game and then wait five minutes.

Traps in the game are often unpredictable and when they aren't killing you out of nowhere they are frustrating you by setting you back several rooms. Many times you will be struck by lightning because you hit a wall that did not look special at all, or a floor will drop from under you and set you back another 5 minutes.

Overall, while I do want to like this game, La-Mulana is filled with so many constant annoyances that it is hard to feel like you are having fun. Having to constantly backtrack around the game while dealing with annoying enemies and traps while constantly being blocked by puzzles is too frustrating for me.

reviewText:
I loved this game at first.  But after I spent some more time with it (time counter isn't wholly accurate, spent a good deal of time playing on a friend's account), that view has changed a good deal.  This game... can be fun.  Its got some cool Indiana Jones-esque elements, good puzzles, and interesting enviroments and boss design.  That's all well and good.  But... the game bills itself as challenging.  I don't agree.  Its hard.  Not Dark Souls hard; not challenging in a way that drives you to want to win, to want to beat the next boss and the next and eventually the game.  Its frustratingly hard.  Unfun hard.  This becomes ESPECIALLY apparent in alot of the boss fights.  First of all, give the arenas a little bit of thought!  The second boss' arena is two platfroms and a ladder.  The first?  A series of floating platforms placed above of each other.  The third?  A minecart run over tracks of varying heights against a boss who you can only damage by hitting his head.  First three bosses weak points are all the head.  Also, this game, particularly in the boss fights, has some of the worst hitboxes I have seen in a videogame.  We're talking Dark Souls 2 bad.

The game itself doesn't even know what its doing half the time.  For example, sometimes the fireballs on the third boss will do 8 damage, other times 12?  Sometimes you'll get hit by his charge, other times the exact same thing wil happen, the exact same attack, the exact same point of contact between the PC and the boss, and nothing will happen.

Also noob traps.  SO MANY NOOB TRAPS.

Doesn't rate a buy, and CERTAINLY not at $15.00.

reviewText:
It sucks.
Edit:
That was too simple I suppose, though I still stand by that statement.  Here's an actual review:

This is going to sound really bad, but...
It's too hard.
It's a throwback to the nes days where you weren't given a manual most of the time because people threw the boxes to their games away, and even if you got a manual it wasn't very useful for most games.

This game is linear with a mostly set path, but you are given very little aid in finding it.  This game can be beaten very fast if you go through a what-to-do checklist from a site like gamefaqs, but people say that this is a terrible idea as it ruins the fun of the game.

That's right, most people will tell you that the fun of this game, which is a side-scrolling platformer, does not come from gameplay mechanics and interesting fights, but instead from working against the attrition you suffer while trying to find where to go.  The gameplay is fairly solid, but even the most seasoned player will take damage as they work through figuring out what to do.  This would be fine if the game didn't have two very unnecessary punishment elements to it:

Healing is difficult.
When you die, you die.  Progress lost.

As I stated earlier, this is a throwback to the NES era of games, but I don't think it's a good thing.  The 80's were 30 years ago; We've advanced in technology.  A game doesn't need to be extended by punishing mechanics anymore.  Not many people have the time to just say oh
date:
I died into a dungeon I couldn't survive because I wasn't supposed to come here yet.  I didn't need that 30 minutes anyways."  Punishing exploration is a good way to dissuade people from wanting to explore.

Think about whether you think a game should be punishing at all anyways.  Does it make it more fun?  Is it fun to get so angry that you want to snap your controller in half because you just lost an hour because of some spikes or from falling into a pit of water?

Somewhere in La Mulana there is a good game with great mechanics and an interesting environment/story to explore.  I just don't like that it's buried beneath a bunch of design decsions that make the game hard for the sake of being hard."

reviewText: La-Mulana is an unfortunate game in that the music, design and concept are great, but requiring you to use a walkthrough to play a game is just ridiculous in this day and age.  People complain about games like Simon's Quest requiring you to use a guide to get through, but that was due to horrible localization.  If translated correctly, you could play through the game without the use of a guide.  I am not going to resort to a walkthrough or video guide in order to play this.  Just going to throw in the towel and accept that the money is gone.  I read previous reviews that stated that the game was a challenge, but when I hear the word challenge, I think of difficulty as in smart AI, brutal levels, etc.  This game is not challenging, it's uninformative.  It just refuses to tell you how to play or what to do.  That's just not fun to me.

reviewText:
I bought this game expecting Castlevania SoTN 2 (good) and I ended up getting Castlevania 2 Enhanced edition (bad).
This game does nothing to guide you. You can miss buying the very indispensable items you need to get through the game and, yet, it lets you mess around for hours until you start feeling like the game is broken.
It's way too open-ended. You can go through areas you are not supposed to - due to the lack of items you need -, save the game in there, and find yourself trapped trying to either advance or get back to where you came from.
It's unjustifiably hard. Every clue is cryptic; it feels like you're supposed to write everything down and unravel a mystery while killing red skeletons - really? I had to kill the red skeletons to get that extra stone block to solve the freaking puzzle? where the hell was a clue about that?
Yet, I feel compelled to finish it. If you plan on finishing this game too, I recommend watching a guide for the first part of the game to get the feel of it and not get surprised by its open-endedness.

reviewText:
A nostalgic game with great possibilities, I fail to see as much enjoyability in the gameplay. The game is too hard, elusive, and the physics are sub-par.

GAMEPLAY
When jumping, you are constricted from free movement till the apex of the jump, making it partially more realistic but still not physically accurate. Why not just have it be the old-fashioned method as seen in SNES Mario games where you can move freely in the jump? Also, when you are hit, you are stunned - you fall stories from a ladder, to land at the bottom. You can not course-correct if you've been hit off an edge or a ladder. This means if there's an enemy guarding the ladder, it's a frustrating and idiotic obstacle. And you cannot jump onto a ladder, or drop from a ladder to save time.

Also, where you are supposed to in the game, what exactly an item does, etc., is too subtle. Some of the humor is cute, some of it detracts from the immersive world. It is too easy to die between saves, so I will have to get into the habit if playing more carefully and saving at save stations often. No quicksive in the game, as far as I can see.

AUDIO
The music is nice, but lacks in bass and is too repetitive. Why not something more like the gems of music in Final Fantasy 6?

GRAPHICS
And one final issue: the game seems to be of the old, pixelated fashion. SNES was not designed this way for kicks, but for limiations. They did a great job on the graphics back in the day, and it worked for common TV screens. These days, we have large resolution screens with games of high potential, like La-Mulana, which fall short not only in stilted gameplay but with limited, 8-bit graphic stylization. If most gamers have a large resolution screen in 2013, the sprites should be created at a high, standard resolution (think 1920x1200,) and then downscaled to a measely 800x600, which is the standard this PC game is designed at.

Lovely game, high potential, but the controls do not give you that fluid upper-hand you'd expect for a challenging retro game. Give us proper physics, and you'll have a much better game.

reviewText:
I like this game... but I don't think I can recommend it to most people. It's the most obtuse, intentionally confusing, and ruthless pixel adventure game I've played, and I've played a lot of them. That being said, the art and music are gorgeous and the design feels old-school in all the right ways.

But when I've got to spend hours just trying to figure out how to end the second level, before finally succumbing to a walkthrough and STILL being lost, that's just bad design. There's nintendo hard, and then apparently there's MSX hard.

If you're a hardcore gamer who likes platformers and has already beaten Cave Story, I'd suggest it. But to anyone else, I'd say wait until the sequel.

reviewText:
La-Mulana is probably one of my favorite video games, with bosses and puzzles that are actually challenging.
However...
This is the remake, and it tries way too hard to be different.

This is the worst kind of remake, the kind that changes way too much.  The point of a remake is so that you can run the game on newer computers, not so you can play the same game, but with irksome changes here and there.  The difficulty curve is all messed up because they changed too much.  Not to mention, at least for me, the Remake runs WORSE than the original does.  I'm aware that if you've never played the original, then the differences won't be as offputting.  Although, I do believe you should just play the original anyway.

Don't get me wrong, it's still a good" game.  It's just not nearly as good as the original version.

Only get this game if you somehow refuse to go through the work of getting the original to run
date: or you want to play it with stereoscopy."

reviewText: The ultimate ruins exploration game. Filled to the brim with clever riddles, devious traps, and head-scratching puzzles, this game will frustrate you more than any other, but in all the right ways. Like all the best Metroid/Castlevania style games, progress is almost completely based on gaining new abilities and equipment to solve old puzzles and reach new areas. Along with all this comes solid music and really great bosses. Plenty of cool nods to all kinds of obscure mythology and ruins from the real world, too.\n\nSpend some time in La-Mulana, solve the mystery of the ruins, and find the Secret Treasure of Life.

reviewText: I love this game. Even after almost 6 hours I've only found and defeated one boss, but I rarely feel like I'm wandering around aimlessly. I feel like I'm gathering clues to solve a huge puzzle...and most of the time that's exactly what I'm doing. Every time I backtrack I find something new, or decipher a cryptic note I didn't understand the last time. It's like a tougher and more puzzle-oriented Super Metroid with some I Wanna Be The Guy-style traps. Hints come in the form of emails from the village elder as well, but they're not too revealing, just a little nudge to help you get going. Expect to be writing some things down on your journey.\n\nMy only complaint is the controls, which I suppose are supposed to be realistic, but even after 6 hours I'm still not used to them. When you jump you're committed to it; forward jumping has a set arc depending on how high you jump that can't be interrupted, and jumping straight up is uncontrollable until you reach the height of the jump. Falling off a ledge forces you to plummet straight down. It's somewhat irritating at times, but it's tolerable.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
One of my favourites. The bosses are all unique and most will surprise you (most bosses have changed completely from the original game). La-Mulana probably has the most consistently great soundtrack of any game I have played.

I tried to stay clean and beat it on my own, but like many others, looking through loads of screenshots to figure what to do became tiresome after around 70% of progress. I am pretty patient when it comes to games, but I do not regret looking up how to solve some of the last puzzles, I never would have figured them out. It's not for everyone. Other than the difficulty of some of the later puzzles, some things like the jumping physics, and instant death traps (which aren't really a big deal - even if you forget to save often there is a frequent auto-save feature at certain points) may turn some players away. The way the player jumps was intentional and the platforming in the game was designed around it, so it rarely bothered me. I actually found it pretty fun to figure out the little nuances of the jump, and it just felt like part of the challenge to me.

Even though I was finding myself at a loss near the end, I kept going because I felt like I had to complete this game. It's one of those games (like Metroid) where if you stop playing for a while, it will take you ages to remember what you were even doing and what you have access to. Also it's damn good. I think it's well worth the price, it's much deeper and more polished than I expected. At least now I can finally delete all those tablet screenshots.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best games I've ever played as well as one of the hardest.

Action-wise... the game is tough but fair.  The standard enemies are not a terrible threat, but they'll wear you down over time if you're not careful.  The bosses are quite challenging, require practice to beat, but many of them can be made easier by outscaling them with power-ups.

The puzzles though... Oh god... Mercy... I thought I was doing pretty well at first, but after getting about a third of the way into the game, I was stuck.  This game is full of moon logic" puzzles.  Even if you are very meticulous in taking notes

reviewText:
The game starts off great. It gives you clues on how to progress and vague goals. I've got a little notebook by my computer, and it's been fun to write down the clues I get and writing notes, it feels like actual exploration in a way I've never seen in a game before.

But, uh.

Remember that part in Super Metroid where you get the power bomb and wander around for a couple hours trying to figure out what to do wih it? And then you finally manage to blow up the glass tube that gets you in Maridia, and you think to yourself, How on earth was I supposed to know to do that?"

Yeah. Welcome to that
date: the videogame. The middle to end of this game is effectively that
hoursPlayed: for a number of hours. Rather than difficulty
voteText: the game goes straight into obscurity. The clues go from helpful to extremely vague and start making sense only after the fact ("...Oh
helpfulPercent: /that/'s what that meant.") You'll (sometimes) have a vague sense of what needs to be done - or rather
votesHelpful: a collection of things that /can/ be done
votesTotal: though whether or not you're actually able to do them yet is unknown - and no idea how to do them or where to get them. It stops giving you goals on what you're supposed to be doing
votesFunny: removes any feeling of progression
commentsCount: and the game boils down to revisiting every area over and over and over again in the vague hope of finding something new. And when you do find something new
column16: the experience is fleeting

column18:
wildly far from you.


TL;DR: unless you are a masochist with rediculous amounts of free time and patience

and there can be value in that.


All that said

reviewText:
One fool believed, in his foolishness, that he was a wise man. The fool flaunted his shallow wisdom and made decisions with a narrow mind. He proceeded to the right without hesitation.

Another fool possessed wisdom, but his knowledge led him to believe he was a fool. A fool who smothers himself without first considering the situation. He went with the flow, and proceeded to the left.

One can only hope that a true wise man stands here now.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

La-Mulana is not for the faint of heart or weak of mind. This is NOT a game where you can grind until you're strong enough to win. This is NOT a game where you can skip the lore and expect to succeed. And this is most certainly NOT a game where you can expect an easy victory just because you looked up the puzzle solutions online.

Despite what my Steam records say, I've beaten this game twice now. (First the original, then a non-Steam release of this remake.) And neither time was easy in the slightest. You want fun? Play this. You want bland tedium that will atrophy your brain? Play your Call of Warbattles or Flappy Crush.

La-Mulana is more than a video game; It's a test of character.

(Soapboxing aside, I have to point out that the Linux version seems kinda janky. Just a warning.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText: I really like the game.\n\nThe graphics are nostalgic, the concept is marvelous, and the bosses are so rage inducing that you'll feel a wave of motivation and progress once you move forward. reviewText:
This has been my favorite game ever since the Japanese Wii release. When I first ever played this game, I couldn’t figure what the heck I was supposed to do. That was until I learned you can use the challis to teleport out of the temple and back to the surface, and that’s where the rea fun begins.

The basic idea of the game is for players to transverse through a very large and difficult temple, filled with items that make your more powerful, traps that cause massive amounts of damage, monsters who try to get in your way, and gigantic boss who try to kill you quickly. Once a player gets into a dire state, they are teleport out of the temple to heal themselves and then return back to the temple to try to get even deeper into La-Mulana.

This game is not for everyone, it can be extremely frustrating and will most likely cause you to run around in circles for hours trying to figure out what the heck to do next. What makes it fun to me is the fact that it is extremely challenging and each puzzle’s solution is hidden in a mystery; they don’t hold your hand like most games do these days.

I grew up in a video game era were video games would just throw you into the action and it was up to you to you figure it out yourself. This game takes me back to that time and every time I solved a puzzle on my own, I feel happily rewarded as I progress even deeper through LA-Mulana.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Some warnings up-front: this game can be hard to get into.  The controls aren't explained well initially, and it takes time to get a feel for the platforming mechanics, which are fairly idiosyncratic.  It's not an easy game either; it pulls very few punches and is much stingier than most modern games about checkpoint placement and health recovery.  There are also several fairly tough puzzles that require some creative interpretation of the sometimes-badly-translated hints strewn throughout the game.\n\nDespite all of the above, this is quite simply one of the largest and most satisfying Metroidvania games I've ever played.  The maps are massive, the backstory is interesting and integrated into the puzzles.  The power-ups are fun, and the weapons provide enough variety to be satisfying without being numerous enough that any of them feel like afterthoughts.  In terms of content for the price, this game is an absolute steal.  If you have the chops for it, bring your action-platformer and adventure-game-puzzler A-games and take this one on right away.

reviewText: This game is a fantastic throwback to the old school 2D adventure games.  It's a Metroidvania, there are plenty of skills and items to find, etc.\nThere are a lot of good things to say about this game.  The combat is great.  You start with only a whip but you get different items over time including a Katana.  The menu system is very innovative; your character is equipped with a mobile PC which has multiple functions including deciphering ancient tablets and using your map!  You can equip and unequip these programs" depending on how much "memory" you have available in your PC!\nThe puzzles are interesting.  This game will make you think
date: but it's also action packed!\n\nThe only problem I have is the old school jumping mechanics.  Like in the classic 2D adventure games of old
recommended: you can't change direction in mid-jump.  You're committed once you're in the air.  Also
hoursPlayed: when you fall from a ledge
voteText: you're forward momentum stops and you fall straight down.  If you want to move horizontally
helpfulPercent: you'll have to jump first!  You CAN control the height of your jump
votesHelpful: however.\n\nAnother con is the resolution.  If you have a 16:9 monitor
votesTotal: you'll have bars on the right and left sides
votesFunny:
but you can enable cool artwork to take up that space!

This is one of those games where you have to do a little bit of researching the manual.  You need some things from the merchants in the starting area before you can fully explore.

All in all

reviewText: I love this game. Even after almost 6 hours I've only found and defeated one boss, but I rarely feel like I'm wandering around aimlessly. I feel like I'm gathering clues to solve a huge puzzle...and most of the time that's exactly what I'm doing. Every time I backtrack I find something new, or decipher a cryptic note I didn't understand the last time. It's like a tougher and more puzzle-oriented Super Metroid with some I Wanna Be The Guy-style traps. Hints come in the form of emails from the village elder as well, but they're not too revealing, just a little nudge to help you get going. Expect to be writing some things down on your journey.\n\nMy only complaint is the controls, which I suppose are supposed to be realistic, but even after 6 hours I'm still not used to them. When you jump you're committed to it; forward jumping has a set arc depending on how high you jump that can't be interrupted, and jumping straight up is uncontrollable until you reach the height of the jump. Falling off a ledge forces you to plummet straight down. It's somewhat irritating at times, but it's tolerable.

reviewText:
I haven't enjoyed a game like this in YEARS.

I'd best describe La-Mulana as 'Castlevania: Symphony of the Night' with the go-where-you-want/progress-how-you-will attitude of the original 'The Legend of Zelda'.  The game world it presents, ends up being a large, well-trodden one, full of cryptic puzzles, whose solutions often grant you a piece to solving a greater puzzle.

If you enjoy “tough but fair” games, and/or are in the market for a lengthy journey, I'd give La-Mulana a look.

P.S. Crybabies need not apply.

reviewText: La-Mulana is a very cool old school platformer with nice pixel art graphics. Explore the ruins and solve its puzzles. And if you cannot solve a room or defeat a monster right away, return later when you have more items. You can save the game at save points. If you die you have to reload. There are no checkpoints and there's quite a bit of backtracking. Like the platformers of old you have little control while jumping and no control while falling. Also, you cannot jump through platforms. This may frustrate some players who are used to games like Terraria.\nThe game starts in windowed mode, but you can switch to full screen and pick any resolution and also choose two filtering (blurring) options if you don't want to see sharp pixels.

reviewText:
La-Mulana is a Metroidvania style game where you play as a Japanese take on Indiana Jones as you adventure to and explore the ruins of La-Mulana, the origin of all mankind in this world.
There are plenty of puzzles and traps to see in the ruins that will keep you on your toes, this is also perhaps also one of the games faults as you WILL be doing look ups on walktroughs to break some of the game's more challenging puzzles. If you haven't had to look up a solution by the time you reach the Gate of Illision, you will then.
The combat and movement is very finely tuned, not too often did I feel that my death was unjustified, it was usually due to my own lack of skill or even missing critical equipment for an encounter. Movement is pretty smooth even though you lack movement mid-jump, even after learning how to double jump. Upon recovering the Hooly Grail after solving a few simple puzzles in the enterance of La-Mulana you will gain the ability to teleport between save points from anywhere inside this sprawling dungeon.
Health recovery in this game is a little strange, you recover your HP by sitting on hot springs or by collecting enough EXP from green orbs dropped by foes to equal the full length of your health bar upon which your EXP will be reset to 0 and your HP will be fully restored to %100 reguardless of how much health you have at the time. With this health recoverly system you w
The lore you will discover in the ruins paint an interesting spin on the origin of mankind and even how mankind ends in the La-Mulana world. This game is genininely worth a look and I highly reccomend it.

It's only negative is that it's slightly easier than the freeware version. It's up to you to know if this is a good thing or a bad thing.\n\nDefinitely get it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Absolutely stunning game, and I thought it was just gona be another ho hum metroid like and short little game.

This game annihilates all other metroidvania games, even SUPER METROID, in my opinion anyways. The sheer majesty of this game is shocking. From the humble and simple beginnings of just swinging my whip at snakes to collect gold, never would I have imagined the insane depth and enjoyment that would follow for a massive sprawling adventure.

It took me 80 hours to beat the game and I only looked up a few things... Shamefully... an experience this phenomonal SHOULD BE PLAYED WITHOUT A GUIDE, no matter how stuck you think you are. You CAN solve pretty much every puzzle without a guide, but only if you think deeply and carefully. You really do get the sense of being like Indy Jones, reading, studying, obsessing over the many cryptic hints sprawled all over. The game can be solved in different ways with different levels of item completion, oh, and it has a hardcore mode too, as if it wasn't hard enough already!
This kind of cryptic riddle solving is usually not my type of game, and yet I found myself hopelessly addicted to solving the ancient and increasingly fascinating mysteries of La-Mulana.

The reward of finally solving some nasty riddle, or defeating one of the many very challenging bosses is a new visually exciting zone, more awesome powerups, with yet another great music to go with it..... zone after zone.... I was blown away by how big the game was, and how much great music is here. This is one of the most incredible gaming soundtracks in history. The game is worth 15 bucks on the music alone.


Still on the fence about this? Let me put it to you bluntly.....


Did you love Super Metroid?
yeah?

THEN YOU ABSOLUTELY NEED TO PLAY LA-MULANA!!! THERE IS NO EXCUSE! This game is NOT for the weak willed who cry to momma when the game kicks their behind, and it will, time and time again! And it makes no apologies for it. Bats will constantly knock you into spikes, pits, and doom! OH THE FREAKING BATS!!! STOP IT !!! STOOOOOP IT!!!!!! NOOOOOO!!!

L2P NOOB OR DIE!!
Prepare to rage harder then you have EVER raged at a game before. I PROMISE YOU WILL HATE THIS GAME at times! You will SCREAM in anger and agony from that *blankity* horrible and unfair knockback mechanic!.... and yet....... by the end of the game... you should realize it was a big part of the challange and taught you to PLAY BETTER!
I rage quit many times... yet I was helpless and unable to stay away for long. I haved learned to deeply appreciate and love the challenge found in this game.


CONCLUSION----

Tight controls, fun progression with awesome powerups, very challenging, intellectually stimulating, teasingly addictive gameplay, stunning soundtrack, awesome visuals, epic boss battles, humongous game, fascinating story and lore, wicked awesome clever riddles, hard mode, speed run mode, boss rush mode, hell bonus level, a bathing suit, THIS GAME HAS IT ALL! All while kicking your posterior to kingdom come.

I am a very jaded cynical gamer.... and yet..

La-Mulana is one of the GRANDMASTERS, a true CHAMPION of gaming history. I feel sorry for anyone who's too much of a wuss to stick with it and solve it. They are missing out on one of the very best gaming has to offer in 40 years of gaming history period.

reviewText: Probably the most fun I've had with a game in the past 3 or so years. A faithful homage to the crushingly-difficult platformers of yore that doesn't rub that fact in your face. Challenging, but not unfair. Well, usually. There're plenty devious traps and cunning misdrections to frustrate and befuddle.\n\nBut yeah, if you want to play the game that sparked today's brutal Metroidvanias, get this game. Only complaints are with how jumping works (no directional influence until the peak of the jump if starting from a neutral jump) and how you can actually get stuck if you miss a certain item in the beginning. But that item is pretty much in your path, so it's hard to miss.

reviewText:
La-Mulana focuses heavily on riddles and exploring inside a gigantic ruin. Some of these puzzles can be quite difficult to solve, but then you really feel you accomplished something. But even if you feel stuck, just go to another area, as many parts of the ruins can be accessed from the beginning. Others can be reached by obtaining certain items.
There's a lot of different items, main and sub weapons to be found, each serving a certain purpose. So this gets elevated to a Metroidvania-style game.
You even do not have to fight the bosses in a fixed order to progress. As for those boss battles, these are varied as well: There are stationary ones, in one fight you ride a track down in a mine-cart, while the foe follows you.
Awesome.

My only gripe in the game is some very obscure hints for certain puzzles. You probably might have to look up somewhere or trying out a lot there - but be assured, there so much to do in the game, You will never feel bad, if you 'cheated' after you clocked so many hours into the game already. Just check that thing in a suspicious room further (or go somewhere else, as stated above) and move on your own.
The controls themselves are solid and work as intended. Only jumping down below properly needs some practice first. Lemeza falls straight down, if he doesn't jump from a cliff, unable to change direction. Luckily there is no fall damage and many regular enemies only do little damage, except for some sub and main bosses.
Take a hop before jumping on platforms below you - and you can move Lemeza in mid-air. Required for certain puzzles and just being a small hint.
I play the game with a keyboard by the way, while the game has full controller support, including XBOX360 support as in the dscription, and there's no problem with controlling that way as well.

The Graphics are really well done. They are stretched in fullscreen, the aspect ratio is mantainted properly. In widescreen formats the black bars can be decorated with murals and other images by going into the Options menu - which is a nice touch. Each ruin is vastly different, many background objects and statues are unique (and often required to be examined further by the game). There's even a hidden area, where you explore some of the original areas with the MSX-style graphics from the 2005 version.

Music and sound are nicely done as well. While the tracks might repeat too quickly, many of the areas (in my case, e. g. the Temple of Moonlight) have catchy background music, some more decent, others being more dominant. For anyone who likes videogame music, this might be just right. The sound effects help you, be it a breakable wall which makes a certain crumble noise if struck by (certain) weapons, different tunes whenever you fail or solve a puzzle and other effects.

If you don't mind the difficulty at times and love either cool boss battles and some brain-teasing puzzles, get this game ASAP. It's worth every penny, especially at that bargain in this sale.

reviewText: I prefer metroidvania's in comparison to most other games. There's the feeling of exploration that you don't get from other genres, an air of freedom that's restricted only by your equipment and skill, the challenge of reaching something new that's mere inches over the tower of angry crazed monstrocities that haven't tasted food in centuries, just waiting for you to slip... It's amazing.\nLa Mulana definitely met what I was looking for. It's a scarilly difficult game, but it's fantastic. If you're willing to brave the countless monsters lurking around the ruins, and smart enough to outwit the builders of these crazy traps and puzzles, this game is for you. There's treasure to be found, people to help, and a mess of bosses and sub-bosses that will have you rattling the controller in rage... in a good way. The game is beyond the simple word challenging"

recommended: brute force is NOT the answer to the majority of puzzles. You have to be smart with this game. Bosses themselves are a puzzle of what is safe

reviewText:
Great game, very challenging.
I really like the graphics and the music.
The puzzles, well... I got to the point where I deafeated four bosses and acquired the feather, without consulting any external guide (i.e. internet).
But after that, it got way to cryptic and even unfair. False walls, breakable walls, spots where you need to press down, spots where you need to press up,... mostly without any hint. So, don't feel bad if you need a strategy guide at some point(s).

But overall, I recommend this game. A better hint system would have been nice, but I hear that the sequel will aim for less confusion.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
La Mulana is meant to bring back nostalgia for something I've never experienced -- but with its help, now I can.

Although it does not technically require a walkthrough to solve, steam achievements suggest that less than 4% of its player base finishes the game, and I am not surprised.  Less than 3% unlock hell temple (...which involves, among other things, falling for 20 screens down an infinite lava pool and then breaking a false wall...), and I'm pretty sure that less than half a percent finish it.

La Mulana is one of THOSE games.  ..and walkthroughs are plentiful.

It is a personal challenge to anyone that dares try it, and a bragging right to anyone that manages to complete it.  It is full of false walls, obscure puzzles, and insane challenges -- in the most enthusiastically realistic retro fashion.  It is a trap-filled, monster-filled, puzzle-filled dungeon, where you must summon and destroy eight bosses across sixteen-ish zones, collect all manner of random crap, and take advantage of quirky item interactions that you have very little way to foresee.  It is immense, it is gorgeous, it is La Mulana.

It is at this point that you can probably tell whether this sounds torturous or fun to you.  Or maybe a little of both.  It's definitely not for everyone, but it IS fun to watch someone fail at vicariously for a couple hours.  I'll be poking at it as a longterm goal.

reviewText: La-Mulana is a 2d exploration-based platformer, a metroidvania, if you will. You run around a vast interconnected complex of ruins, whipping snakes and skeletons and bats and whatnot, solving puzzles, jumping, falling on spikes, etc. There are many little treasures to collect, powering up your character in some small way, often in such a way that is only really necessary for accessing a single area of the labyrinth, but giving you an actual ability rather than just throwing a key in your hand is a nice touch. The puzzles are many and quite esoteric, which I appreciate, though a few too many of them simply force you to return with some gadget, that more than likely required some other thing to solve its own puzzle. It definitely walks the line between intellectually engaging and tedious. The music is good. Overall the game has a lot of personality, doing things that seem a bit absurd from a design standpoint, but ultimately contributing to that intimate, programmed in somebody's mom's basement kind of feel that make Indie games the joy they are. Or can be, anyway. Where the game falls flat on its face is combat. Wonky collision, tedious enemies, needlessly frustrating bosses, pointless sub weapons, unresponsive controls, obnoxious healing mechanics, it's difficult to name something that was done right in terms of the combat design. The combat and platforming draw heavily, if not entirely, from NES era Castlevania. The whip has a little delay on it, your jump arc can't be altered (much) after you've left the ground, getting hit sends you flyiing, there are subweapons that, hypothetically at least, can fill in the gaps in your offensive capabillities. And that may have worked, if the level and enemy design had been borrowed from NES Catlevania as well. Instead, You find yourself navigating post-Symphony of the Night levels and enemies with pre-Symphony of the Night controls. Enemies move around a lot and in fairly random patterns, hitting them without getting hit yourself is a bit of a gamble (there's a very good reason fleamen only took one hit in Castlevania). You'll routinely find yourself knowcked off platforms and faced with a lengthy trek to return simply because a bat decided to move a certain way at a certain time. Many enemies are simply a matter of sitting and waiting for them to turn their back so you can hit them wothout risking your life (waiting is not skill). The subweapons are slow, weak, and generally go in a straight line, which begs the question of why there are even so many. It uses a bizarre healing mechanic. Enemies drop little health balls, but instead of restoring your health, they fill a bar underneath your health and then, once that bar is filled , all your health. This virtually guarantees that your health will be restored at some arbitrary moment, rather than when you would could actually benefit. Why the balls don't just restore your health directly is beyond me. The system can only be described as asinine. All of this would be tolerable, but what truly sinks the ship are the disastrous boss battles. Don't get me wrong, graphically the bosses are very impressive. Detailed, well animated, room-filling sprites certainly have an appeal about them. But the problem is that a massive room filling monstrosity has to be able to fight the player in such a way that justifies that level of detail. When, for all the charging and fire breath and crumbly cieling bits, the main threat, the biggest factor driving the difficulty of the fight, is not anything the boss is actually doing, but the difficulty inherent in negotiating the tiny area from which you can hit the boss without getting hit yourself, all that detail becomes a bit pointless. For a boss to attack the player in however many unique and interesting ways, but ultimately kill them because the player touched its chin a few too many times shows very bad combat design. I'm going to go farther and say that the concept of the player being hurt by touching enemies is an archaic anachronism and should be done away with. But whatever. Yeah, the game is hard. Hard in a very Dark Souls kind of way, where it's not really so much that you need to get good at it, but that you need to remember stuff and proceed slowly and not break your controller and all that noise. It's punishing and clunky and sort of poorly designed on purpose to make it more difficult. Sometimes that can be nice. I recommend it despite it's flaws. I dunno, play it or don't. It's unique, I respect that.

reviewText: Some warnings up-front: this game can be hard to get into.  The controls aren't explained well initially, and it takes time to get a feel for the platforming mechanics, which are fairly idiosyncratic.  It's not an easy game either; it pulls very few punches and is much stingier than most modern games about checkpoint placement and health recovery.  There are also several fairly tough puzzles that require some creative interpretation of the sometimes-badly-translated hints strewn throughout the game.\n\nDespite all of the above, this is quite simply one of the largest and most satisfying Metroidvania games I've ever played.  The maps are massive, the backstory is interesting and integrated into the puzzles.  The power-ups are fun, and the weapons provide enough variety to be satisfying without being numerous enough that any of them feel like afterthoughts.  In terms of content for the price, this game is an absolute steal.  If you have the chops for it, bring your action-platformer and adventure-game-puzzler A-games and take this one on right away.

reviewText: The ultimate ruins exploration game. Filled to the brim with clever riddles, devious traps, and head-scratching puzzles, this game will frustrate you more than any other, but in all the right ways. Like all the best Metroid/Castlevania style games, progress is almost completely based on gaining new abilities and equipment to solve old puzzles and reach new areas. Along with all this comes solid music and really great bosses. Plenty of cool nods to all kinds of obscure mythology and ruins from the real world, too.\n\nSpend some time in La-Mulana, solve the mystery of the ruins, and find the Secret Treasure of Life.

reviewText:
A great Metroidvania platformer with a good sense of boss design and challenge but poor conveyance on puzzles.

Presentation:

This is a standard 16 bit 2D graphics. Nothing technically special but the environments are based off designs of various cultures throughout the world. Enemies are based off some form of mythology. The bosses start off fairly intimidating then you encounter a satanic goat.

The sound track is great and there's even a sound test within the game. There's a variety of instruments used.

Story:

You play an archelogist named Lemeza who tries to search for his father in the La Mulana Ruins. The lore of this game is found on ancient tablets and you piece together them to learn the history of this place.

Lemenza is a silent protagonist but there are other characters that offer hints to you adventure but are still somewhat funny. There's the old man obsessed with video games and like to tell obvious lies that are funny because how blunt it is. Too bad every other character is just exposition or shopkeepers telling you to buy something.

Gameplay:

The controls are fine with keyboard but platforming is like Castlevania I on NES.
Jumping while moving gives you little control in manuvering your jump, but standing still and jumping will pause you in place for a second and then given full control of you jump. This isn't too much of a problem espcially once you get the double jump. The worst part of the platforming is when you walk off a ledge. You lose any form of movement until you reach the ground. This can be really annoying since you will climb up long vertical shafts.

You gain a large number of powerups and weapons that will help you through La Mulana. Weapons have different attack arcs that can help you hit certain enemies much easilly but you will probably stick with the whip with its hidden upgrades or the axe which has an excellent attack arc.

There's also sub weapons that provides a ranged attack that run on individual ammo system that can be switched around easilly once you find them. Weapons range from surikens to a very expensive but deadly pistol.

There's usable items that only serve the purpose of opening certain areas or reading tablets. There is one however that is very overpowered and can break nearly every sub boss.

The powerups are fairly simple to increased HP or movement speed, but none of them really change the game except the double jump powerup.

The last items you collect is computer software. Most of these items are either hidden or can bought in the store. They do various things like giving a map of the area granted you have the map of the place, or translate stone tablets. There's also hidden software combinations that cause special changes but you really don't know what it did.

The normal enemies are good in variety but some are designed just to make platforming really annoying. There's a medusa head like enemy that shoots arrows at you. They also cause the Lemeza to have knockback which can be very annoying when platforming.

Most sub bosses you encounter can be dispatched with full HP with little strategy and the ones that can't be dispatched either test your paitence or requires actual skill. The main bosses are all pretty challening but lack variety of moves. Once you learn to dodge them while still able to deal damage, then they are no problem.

Outside of fighting and platforming are puzzles and secrets throughout the entire place of La Mulana Ruins. Now this is the biggest strength and its biggest flaw. Be prepared to take notes on stone tablets because those will be hints to puzzles in the zone you are or in a completely different area.

Some of the tablets are pretty clever.

However, some are just vague. There's one that requires you to pause the game in certain places. Then find a hidden warp pipe that leads to 4 tablets that gives vague one word hints.

The amount of times I had to use a walkthrough is too much. Add some breakable/fake walls, or special hidden locks that can only be opened by a randomized summon.

The good news is that the most vague puzzles are optional and miss nothing too major. There's still some ungodly hidden secrets you need to solve.

If this game did not have puzzles, then it was still be a great game, but some puzzles are pretty good. There's great skill based obstacles you have to go through. This game still is very hard when it comes to combat.

reviewText: A solid improvement to the previous free version of the game if you ask me. The game is now much friendlier and easier to get into than the old version due to the addition of things like the xelpud mailer and Mulbruk which both function as helpful hint systems. Graphics and music are both redone of course, and some puzzles have been altered for the better.\n\nThat said, the puzzles will probably still stump you at some point or another. It's a great game but prepare to dedicate yourself to it by taking notes on every tablet and piece of dialogue, or submit to the idea of occasionally resorting a walkthrough to progress.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Imagine a metroidvania, but with a thick layer of varnish spread all over it. Progressing in La Milon's Secret Castle relies on mastering both the unforgiving jumping physics and extremely obtuse puzzles. The real draw of the game is, the underlying lore and story are closely linked to the puzzles for the most part via reading of tablets covered in cryptic text and primitive drawings where you can almost see the self-satisfied smug of the developer who drew them. Enemies are largely slow-moving piles of hitbox, whereas bosses are piles of hitbox that take up half of the screen. The weapons you're saddled with are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ enough to make the proceedings fairly challenging.

Through the end of all of this suffering and turmoil the rewards definitely await, with no shortage of Chicken McItems you can get your greasy fingers on. If you can take the time to read all the tablets, discern what area the hint originated from, what particular puzzle or setpiece the hint is actually referring to, and cross-reference this information in the same notebook for which you keep track of your Zoloft medication, you clearly deserve this game.

One thing I can attest is that this game helped me reignite the rage within my heart. At times a vein erupts in my forehead, I rip off my shirt and start beating my chest wildly, and it eventually takes 3 social workers and a powerful horse sedative to restrain me. 9/10 game, tell your friends.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games I've played. Incredibly engaging. It's the kind of game that constantly occupies your mind even when you're not playing and makes you start it up again to try stuff you thought about.

Make no mistake though; the difficulty of La-Mulana is brutal. Partly due to its gameplay, but mostly due to its puzzles. Have a pen and paper handy because it's that kind of stuff. Riddles, traps and permanent changes to the dungeons.

As for my play time; I picked this up via Playism before the steam release and sunk about 60 hours in it without managing to beat it. I later bought it on steam for a second attempt and while I got further I still never managed to beat it. I admit defeat, but the journey was a blast.

Warning: this game is very niche. La-Mulana is not for everyone due to its extremely punishing nature, but for everyone else it is an incredible game.

reviewText: Wow, so close and I would never have played this. When I played it the first time, it was kind of frustrating. The controls are kind of awkwards (can't jump from ladders, mid air left/right movement is odd) and I really didn't get a lot of things. For example that you can break pots and that money comes out. Which made me grind snakes for the first part of the game and it is INCREDIBLY frustrating. Almost put it away, but apparently didn't. Here I am, almost 50 hours later, and the game is a BLAST. Challening but still beatable (*cough* still haven't beat it yet though). Very very funny humor, the dialogs are great. The graphics are great. The story is cool. The music is super cool. The whole thing is just a very very good game. If you think it sucks at first, please give it another try and hang in there, it is a whole lot of fun once you get the hang.

reviewText: Not my type of game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
La Mulana is a good game with great puzzles and ♥♥♥♥ controls.

Its an excellent combination of the action-platormer and the puzzle-platformer genres where the puzzle side of things do not hold your hand and are more like riddles (sometimes to the point of complete BS where you'll be spending hours figuring out what exactly the hell the clue means before you eventually cheat and realize there's some crap hidden wall you missed or you have to arbitrarily push down at a certain spot even though you've never had to do that before).

Inscrutable clues, though, are probably the best part of La Mulana. Definitely some rewarding experiences to be found here. The fact that your character's picture beings to look like an insane wannabe batman as you progress is also great.

The worst part of La Mulana is the action-platformer side of things. This is a remake of an older game and that means you'll have to deal with the following anachronistic nonsense:

- Input delays. If you jump straight up and try to move it will take a second before you actually move.
- Locked falls. If you fall straight down instead of jumping down you will not be able to alter your landing.
- Uncontrollable swimming. There's some built up momentum going on here that makes jumping out of water a pain.
- Constantly jumping back when hit. You remember castlevania and its lovely pits, right?
- Grinding for cash. Oddly, the game requires you to buy weights to activate switches and makes you grind for gold.
- Finicky hitboxes. Bosses can only be hurt in the center of their heads, and you have to make sure you get real close for it to count.

The game gives you a lot of tools to try to work your way out of this (as most of the problems with the controls can be mitigated by using the ranged subweapons), but that puts you in the scenario of having to grind your way through parts you're stuck on - which is pretty much impossible as most enemies only drop 2 gold (if you're lucky).

So, the game wants you to fight with the melee wapons. That's fine. I just wish the controls were better. The fact that your jumps have committed arcs you can't maneuver out of really limits how you can safely engage an enemy.
Run in gung-ho and expect to miss and take damage or trade. Even the double-jump power you get later doesn't give you the ability to jump away - you'll just jump further in the direction you were already moving.


Good game. Great puzzles. ♥♥♥♥ controls.

reviewText:
This game is not as difficult as others have said....

La-Mulana is an homage to the older adventure games of the NES era. Castlevania, Battle of Olympus, and Faxanadu all rolled into one great little package.

Just like the games of yester-year, La-Mulana does not hold your hand. It is up to the player to remember all the little details that add up later. To be able to find the hidden entrances that others in a hurry might miss. This game is about the fine details, covering every inch of every room to find your way!

If you enjoy a solid challenge, and a grand adventure (with a little naughty mixed in), La-Mulana awaits!!

reviewText: Good game, quite challenging, you'll need a guide to beat this game. Metroidvania at it's best.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Some things the original does better. Some things this remake does better. If you're at all interested in a game that will not hold your hand, has actual puzzles that require thought and detailed scanning of the ruins, has challenging but fair fights, then I implore you to try the free version for a feel of what the remake has to offer. Oh, if you're afraid of being punished for your mistakes you can just get out now.

You can find everything you need to get started here: http://agtp.romhack.net/project.php?id=lamulana

Running the original version on modern windows require some finangling in the compatability settings, but it's fairly straightforward (Run as admin, compatability mode for XP service pack 2, 16-bit color mode.)

That being said, what this version offers over the original is a more streamlined experience. Some of the puzzles were switched out and brand new ones even thrown in. This updated version is a lot less obtuse. While I hated the new graphics at first, they certainly grew on me and it was nice to hear some of the songs in a modernized format.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
La-Mulana pleasantly surprised me when I first started playing.  Here was a Metroidvania in the strictest sense of the word, with an expansive hand-crafted map just waiting to be explored.  Pivotal items could be found anywhere, so you were constantly rewarded for investigating every nook and cranny.  These upgrades also allowed you to intuitively access new areas--for example, once you acquire an item that lets you breathe underwater, you can progress further in a watery area.

At this point, my only complaints were that save points are few and far between, and are often not located anywhere near bosses.

As I progressed through the game, I grew more and more frustrated.  Upgrades stopped being intuitive since the obstacles they got past became too obviously artificial.  For example, some items interact with arbitrary symbols found throughout the ruins, which you had no reason to believe were important at all.  This leads to a lot of directionless backtracking.

Eventually, I got stuck, looked at a guide, and was shocked at the number of required items that were hidden in unfairly obscure locations.  Stuff like once you do X
date: a ceiling in an unrelated area that you've already explored becomes breakable with your whip".  Maybe a tablet somewhere contains a subtle hint that would point you in the right direction
recommended: but I feel this level of opaqueness is bad game design.  Super Metroid had plenty of hidden secrets
hoursPlayed: but there was almost always something unusual about the area to prompt you to scan it more closely with your X-Ray Scope.\n\nI'm unsure whether I will continue playing La-Mulana
voteText: but if I do
helpfulPercent: I expect to have to rely on a guide.  Despite this
votesHelpful: I do see why the game was so influential
votesTotal: and I still think it has quite a lot to offer."

reviewText:
This game is really, really good. I cheated and played the game with a guide, and *still* had an amazing time with it, and even played the game a couple more times. It's one of the best games ever made. I'm dead serious.

The game has fantastic music, amazing boss fights, and a huge expansive world with an incredibly deep lore. However, the game is full of extremely cryptic puzzles.

Honestly, I recommend that you play this game until you get stuck, then go through the rest of it with a walkthrough. Some of the puzzles in this game are just not reasonable, and it's impossible to tell in advance the difference between reasonable puzzles, unreasonable puzzles, and puzzles you can't solve yet. It is also extremely non-linear, which complicates matters.

If you want to beat this game without help, I recommend against it, but here's my advice. There's very little in the game that is blatantly not hinted at, but many of the hints are extremely cryptic. Get a notepad and write down every single hint you come across (or screenshot them). And don't come into it with the attitude that you're going to clear one area at a time; after the initial Gate of Guidance, you have to hop back and forth between areas frequently to progess. Many of the puzzles require out-of-the-box thinking so be ready for that. Read the manual and watch the Beginner's Guide. This game is tough as nails, and beating it is a project. Expect it to take hundreds of hours (if you use a guide, 10 hours). This is a real game.

For my friends, I love this game, and I know it inside and out, so if you want me to hint you in the right direction instead of resorting to a guide, I'm happy to talk about it any time.

reviewText: Challenging, puzzling, and amazing. La-Mulana throws you into a massive world, with no sense of direction. You're introduced to three huts, one open, and you're told to explore, but how deep can those ruins go? At times, is may get frustrating due to the fact you may forget something important, or get stumped by a hard boss fight. No matter what though, do not loose hope, and explore what the ruins have in store for you!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: La-Mulana is an absolutely fantastic game. Personally, I've lost count of how many times I've played through it. I've even beaten Hell Temple once, though that was on the Playism version. Yes, this game was good enough that I bought it twice. Anyway.\n\nLa-Mulana is an open-world platformer that sends you, an archaeologist, delving into the eponymous ruins of La-Mulana. At first, you're only in it for the treasure, but the plot slowly unfolds into something much bigger than that. The controls, once you know why they are how they are, are fantastic. When I first played it, I was confused why the jumping was so strange, but after I learned that they were done like that to harken back to the MSX game Maze of Galious, it all made sense to me. The enemies, somewhat uniquely for a game like this, are purposefully only annoyances. The real challenge of the game is in its puzzles. While they are completely ingenius, I'm not ashamed to admit I used a guide for a lot of them. Even with that, however, the game was still an awesome experience, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a game that wants you to think.

reviewText:
La-Mulana does not give even the tiniest crap about you, and it's awesome. It wisely understands that playing a game about an action-archaeologist exploring mysterious ruins means hurling you into a confusing unknown, and everything about its play reinforces that. It's fantastically sprawling, fantastically confusing, and fantastically frustrating, but if you enjoy a taste of those elements, this could be the perfect game for you.

It's closest cousin is probably Super Metroid, but La-Mulana trades out the former's tight action gameplay for much, much, much more focus on puzzles and a look-before-you-leap mentality. And not just block-pushing shenanigans. (Though of course there's no shortage of that, of course.) La-Mulana demands that you approach your adventure like an actual archaeologist. You'll need to pay attention to details, take diligent notes, understand the history of the ruins, and never, ever, stop looking for new nooks and crannies to explore. Metroidvania-style games often feature an element of sequence-breaking, allowing diligent/skilled players to tackle the game in unusual orders. La-Mulana stands alone in being so massive and so uninterested in shepherding you along a default path that it's hard to say if there's a designated sequence at all. Even killing major bosses might yield nothing more than a pat on the back. Rare is the game that puts you so thoroughly on your own.

That said, there are a couple of fairly big dings that keep it out of masterpiece territory and closer to cult classic for masochists. For one, puzzles do branch into the realm of insane BS from time to time, and the game introduces (or rather, requires but does not introduce) a couple of unique environmental interactions along the way. Even if this kind of game is right in your sweet spot, keep the wiki bookmarked because you will need it at some point or another. Second, solving a puzzle triggers a confirmation sound effect but doesn't show you what was unlocked, which is a huge problem when the resulting change occurs screens or zones away. And finally, things continue escalating in complexity all the way to the finale. While that would be fine in something like a platformer, here it means that you will absolutely be following a guide for the last big puzzle, and that it doesn't feel like you've come full-circle on the mysteries of La-Mulana so much as the it feels like the game just throwing more and more craziness at you.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Much like the old gods, this game exists. It's far more powerful than us and is just sympathetic enough to allow us pathetic humans to coexist with this behemoth. Our infinitesimal species matters not to this great evil.\n\nThis game doesn't care who you are or how you were raised. Your mother's in the hospital? Your pet just died? Well get over it because La-Mulana doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥. Your sob story has no effect on La-Mulana. In fact your suffering only fuels La-Mulana. It doesn't exist for you and the moment you come to terms with that you'll have an amazing time playing it. I love this game. But god damn does it hate my guts.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Excruciatingly frustrating at times, but something about it keeps you coming back. The puzzles can be really ridiculous, using queer meta elements and truly obtuse clues. I screamed and yelled and cursed at this game but I still soldiered all the way through it. It's unique, and in this day and age I have to tip my hat to any game that can make me feel anything at all. If you stick with it, and forgive yourself for using a guide every now and then, you'll get a very distinct satisfaction upon finishing the game. Suddenly all the other evil puzzle platformers seem a bit more quaint. So be aware! You will get stuck, and you will die on the same rooms/enemies/bosses over and over and over again, but if you can learn to enjoy the pain of defeat, La-Mulana will tenderly embrace you with its sandpaper arms and razorblade fingers. Grab your notebook, and enjoy a different kind of fun.

reviewText:
La-Mulana is a wonderfully difficult metroidvania-game of riddles, with challenging bosses, and a huge game to explore.

There is so much to discover and unfold in the game, part of the fun is finding out how to obtain a new treasure or find a new area to explore. The platforming physics are a bit wonky at first, and can mess up the gaming logic in your head, but it feels fair as you learn how to adapt to it (For example : In-game, if you jump moving right, you can only move right, but if you jump up without moving left or right, you can control your jump more. Also, touching a wall while jumping in a direction can give you back your aerodynamic control).

The main challenge of the game is solving these huge riddles that can really stump you if you don't have a guide, and at times, you might need to look at every aspect of details, or every word the game conveys, just because it can be very vital for solving these challenging puzzles. Aside from the riddles, the game isn't that difficult until you start reaching certain areas (especially in the early-game), or fight bosses (then again, if you're as skilled in video games as I am, hard mode isn't as hard as it seems, despite the extra deaths (which is all apart of the fun in a game)).

At the time of this review, I feel like I'm near mid-game, but I still feel like I just scratched the surface. The soundtrack is amazing, the satisfaction of solving a overly arching riddle is trumendous, and the bosses are quite challenging to fight. I highly recommend this game to the few that won't give up.

(Also, if you're not sure about this game, there is a free version available looming around the internet with older graphics and slightly more frustrating moments, and equally great soundtrack. Just remember to patch the english translations, otherwise you'll get stumped quite easily)(Another thing I'd like to mention is that the official guide for this game is actually super useful!)

reviewText:
La-Mulana pleasantly surprised me when I first started playing.  Here was a Metroidvania in the strictest sense of the word, with an expansive hand-crafted map just waiting to be explored.  Pivotal items could be found anywhere, so you were constantly rewarded for investigating every nook and cranny.  These upgrades also allowed you to intuitively access new areas--for example, once you acquire an item that lets you breathe underwater, you can progress further in a watery area.

At this point, my only complaints were that save points are few and far between, and are often not located anywhere near bosses.

As I progressed through the game, I grew more and more frustrated.  Upgrades stopped being intuitive since the obstacles they got past became too obviously artificial.  For example, some items interact with arbitrary symbols found throughout the ruins, which you had no reason to believe were important at all.  This leads to a lot of directionless backtracking.

Eventually, I got stuck, looked at a guide, and was shocked at the number of required items that were hidden in unfairly obscure locations.  Stuff like once you do X
date: a ceiling in an unrelated area that you've already explored becomes breakable with your whip".  Maybe a tablet somewhere contains a subtle hint that would point you in the right direction
recommended: but I feel this level of opaqueness is bad game design.  Super Metroid had plenty of hidden secrets
hoursPlayed: but there was almost always something unusual about the area to prompt you to scan it more closely with your X-Ray Scope.\n\nI'm unsure whether I will continue playing La-Mulana
voteText: but if I do

At first, you're only in it for the treasure, but the plot slowly unfolds into something much bigger than that. The controls, once you know why they are how they are, are fantastic. When I first played it, I was confused why the jumping was so strange, but after I learned that they were done like that to harken back to the MSX game Maze of Galious, it all made sense to me. The enemies, somewhat uniquely for a game like this, are purposefully only annoyances. The real challenge of the game is in its puzzles. While they are completely ingenius, I'm not ashamed to admit I used a guide for a lot of them. Even with that, however, the game was still an awesome experience, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a game that wants you to think.

reviewText:
Some things the original does better. Some things this remake does better. If you're at all interested in a game that will not hold your hand, has actual puzzles that require thought and detailed scanning of the ruins, has challenging but fair fights, then I implore you to try the free version for a feel of what the remake has to offer. Oh, if you're afraid of being punished for your mistakes you can just get out now.

You can find everything you need to get started here: http://agtp.romhack.net/project.php?id=lamulana

Running the original version on modern windows require some finangling in the compatability settings, but it's fairly straightforward (Run as admin, compatability mode for XP service pack 2, 16-bit color mode.)

That being said, what this version offers over the original is a more streamlined experience. Some of the puzzles were switched out and brand new ones even thrown in. This updated version is a lot less obtuse. While I hated the new graphics at first, they certainly grew on me and it was nice to hear some of the songs in a modernized format.
